USAGE DEFINITION: Read code ever recorded AND any prescription in the last 12 months.
PROVENANCE: Read code list created by Cambridge CPRD team, sourced from QOF and 10.1136/bmj.g330. Run with prescription list in the last 12 months.
CITATIONS:
OURS, DEVELOPED from:

Kontopantelis E, Springate D, Reeves D, Ashcroft DM, Valderas JM, Doran T. Withdrawing performance indicators: retrospective analysis of general practice performance under UK Quality and Outcomes Framework. BMJ 2014;348:g330.
 
&

http://www.pcc-cic.org.uk/article/qof-business-rules-v240

USAGE DEFINITION: Read code ever recorded AND any prescription in the last 12 months.
PROVENANCE:
List generated October 2017 by a GP Duncan Edwards using the CPRD product code browser (using a database up to date within CPRD to July 2017).
I used BNF chapters 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3.1 and 3.3.2 (but not 3.3.3 as these are COPD meds only).
Within 3.1, nebuliser diluents (i.e. saline solutions not containing medicines), drug delivery devices & peak flow meters were excluded.
The top 10 most common medications found in the initial lists were searched by product name, e.g. *salb* and *ventol* to find any medications used for asthma in the database that hadn’t been assigned a BNF code; this found small numbers of rarely used additional codes which were added.
